user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Initialize:
```c
void OS_BSP_Initialize(void)
{
    FILE *              fp;
    char                buffer[32];
    pthread_mutexattr_t mutex_attr;
    int                 status;

    /*
     * If not running as root, check /proc/sys/fs/mqueue/msg_max
     *
     * This special file represents the max depth of a POSIX message queue for an unprivileged user.
     *
     * In order to facilitate running in simulation mode without any need for root access --
     * this will allow the OSAL to successfully create message queues by truncating anything larger than this size.
     *
     * No need to check _LINUX_OS_ here; if the file fails to open, i.e. if not on Linux and the file does not exist,
     * then leave well enough alone and don't do anything.
     */
    if (geteuid() != 0)
    {
        fp = fopen("/proc/sys/fs/mqueue/msg_max", "r");
        if (fp)
        {
            if (fgets(buffer, sizeof(buffer), fp) != NULL)
            {
                OS_BSP_Global.MaxQueueDepth = OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(strtoul(buffer, NULL, 10));
                BSP_DEBUG("Maximum user msg queue depth = %u\n", (unsigned int)OS_BSP_Global.MaxQueueDepth);
            }
            fclose(fp);
        }
    }

    /* Initialize the low level access mutex (w/priority inheritance) */
    status = pthread_mutexattr_init(&mutex_attr);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutexattr_init: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    status = pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_PRIO_INHERIT);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    status = pthread_mutex_init(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex, &mutex_attr);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_init: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: OS_BSP_Initialize has no function parameters, so Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified) does not apply directly within this function. There are no assignments to any function parameter variables in the code shown. The code does pass pointers (e.g. buffer, &mutex_attr, &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex) to library/OS functions; modifying the object pointed to is permitted by the rule, and there is no evidence in this fragment that any pointer parameter (i.e., a parameter variable) is being assigned to. Calls to standard/OS functions (fgets, strtoul, pthread_mutexattr_init, pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol, pthread_mutex_init, fopen, fclose, strerror) are external and their internal handling of their own parameters is outside this function’s scope; nothing in this code assigns to a parameter variable. Therefore there are no code fragments here that require investigation for Rule 17.8.
